segments.text: Translation, Paulette landed back in the country at dusk and immediately traveled to her family in Ashkelon.
She knew that the first thing the next day she would make her way to the pink house, hoping to explain everything face to face.
She didn't know how they would react upon seeing her and feared they might be a little angry that she had suddenly disappeared one day.
Or perhaps not.
Perhaps they would simply be happy with her as always.
She felt a bit guilty.
A year earlier, she unexpectedly received a performance contract in Paris.
So on the spur of the moment and without much preparation, she just got on a plane and vanished for a whole year without saying goodbye or uttering a word.
Twice she even sent them a postcard without an address just so they'd know she was thinking of them.
Paris was good to her and she experienced considerable success along with a good contract with Sabra.
However, to her surprise, she missed home.
And when Sharif San offered her a regular gig at his nightclub in Jaffa, she didn't think twice and returned.
And indeed, the next morning she collected herself and simply walked the 150 meters, separating her family's house from the pink house.
walking towards her little piece of heaven, that small and magical place where no matter when she arrived, she was always welcome, could shed all her masks and be one hundred percent herself.

Just Polette, with her songs and the piano available to her at all times, most of the shutters were closed, and although this seemed a bit strange, she didn't stop to think about it and simply pressed the door handle, which opened wide under her hand.
The dining room was dim, with a dusty smell hanging in the air.
The first thing she noticed was that the piano was gone.
Then she saw that the walls were completely bare of Yosef's paintings.
Apart from that, everything was as it was, even the old armchair in the corner.
Hello, hello, she called out in a slightly frightened voice.
Anybody here?
But no one was there.
The house wasn't locked, an unused object, as if a ghost had passed through and frozen the place.

She slumped, stunned into the armchair, not understanding what had happened here, only knowing they were gone and she didn't know what she would do without this place that was a second home for her, a refuge.

For a while, she lay there, lost in her thoughts, wondering where they were now, what they were doing, and how everything remained in place, including the bottles at the bar and the glasses on the shelves, and why the door wasn't locked.
Who owns this place now?
As if in response to her questions, the door suddenly swung open and a tall, thin, young man stood in the doorway and looked at her in bewilderment.
Hey, I recognize you," he said in English.
You're the singer, right?
What are you doing here?
Didn't you know the hotel was sold?
She collected herself a bit, still seated in Yosef's armchair.
No, I'm in complete shock, she said in a hoarse voice.
I was abroad for a year and just returned yesterday.
What happened?
How is it that everything remains as it was?
Are you the one who bought the place?
Yes, he said, extending his hand to her for a handshake.
Yehuda, very nice to meet you.
A minute later she said sadly, know this.
It's not the same house without the piano and Yosef's paintings on the walls.
Silence fell between them.
The truth is, I haven't decided what I will do with this place yet.
I also used to come here for many years and loved it very much.
They didn't take the furniture because there was nothing to do with it in a regular apartment.
Yes, she said.
But at least the armchair, that's their armchair.
He pondered for a moment before answering her.
I think Yosef was quite broken by the situation and just wanted to leave everything behind.
He mainly packed his paintings carefully.
A few decorations Lucy collected from the flea market and the samovar that stood near the bar.
The more personal items.
Some of the paintings are still packed in the small room near the bathroom because he didn't have room for all of them.
He'll come back to get them when he finds space.
He has a new.
Partner and he moved in with her in her apartment in Tel Aviv and the daughter enlisted in the army more than four months ago.
The story with Leora hurts me the most.
She was in my sister's class and I've known her since she was born.
A special girl mischievous and smiling on one hand, mature for her age on the other and suddenly thrown out into the street.
It's illogical.
I tried to convince Yosef to insist with the Afridar company to leave the unit with the kitchenette and shower for her so she'd have a place to stay.
And I'd buy just the rest.
But he didn't do it.
Maybe he was afraid that's how she'd break away from him.
In hindsight, it was a big mistake.
It would have left her a corner of her own and also an asset she could sell in the future.
I'm almost sure they would have agreed.
They knew him for years and loved him and Lucy very much.
But as they say, don't cry over spilled milk.
You understand, she said.
It was a refuge for me, no less than a shelter, a place of unconditional love.
I love them so much.
I almost ran on the way here.
And they returned love to me like family, more than family.
Always happy to see me.
Joseph would just see me, immediately handing me a shot of Quantro to warm up.
And our girl, she's been an adult for several years, even when she was still a teenager, always with a smile on her face, despite the sadness over Lucy's passing.
And what an ear!
Every song I sing and play, she plays right after me.
She listens and learns.
She knows my entire repertoire.
Now, she smiled.
You know, before the war, I performed with her for soldiers in the Negev.
Just as she is, barefoot, in jeans and a T-shirt, we placed a piano on a horse cart and performed.
And she even wrote Hebrew lyrics to the famous American song, Yippee-y-yay-yay, in honor of the Air Force.
I still sing it in performances, even abroad, and people stand up and clap."
For a moment, she remained silent, then suddenly lifted her beautiful alto voice and sang, yippee-yay-yay, yippee-yay-yo.
He recognized the song.
Did she write Hebrew words for that?
He shot her an amazed look.
Yes, she replied to him.
And after a moment of silence, added quietly, Know this, nothing will ever be the say without the pink house.
Without realizing it, they talked for an hour.
He dragged a chair from the dining room and sat across from her.
You're right, he said to her.
You know, there's something that I can't get out of my mind.
Many years ago, at the start of my path, when I tried to make a living as a newlywed, I went from house to house, selling fans that also warmed, something new that just came on the market.
It didn't really work, but when I got to Lucy, she first made me coffee and then bought two fans for me.
I'm almost sure she didn't need them, but I felt that she just wanted to encourage me and also understood I needed a livelihood.
It unsettles me that in the end, I was the one who bought the pink house and at a bargain price because there were many debts and there was an auction due to Lucy's oldest daughter.
I comfort myself that if it wasn't me, it would have been someone else and maybe they would have paid even less.
I haven't decided what to do with this house yet.
In the end, I'll probably sell it to private people, and it'll go back to being four houses as it was before they turned it into a hotel.
He looked at her for a moment with a sad smile.
I can offer you a shot of Cointreau from the bar, but it's been standing there for months.
Taste it if it's still good."
No thanks, she declined his offer.
That's something that will always stay just between me and Yosuf, a mutual sign between us.
Yehuda sat for a long time after she left.
The break away from the disappearance of the pink house from his life reminded him all at once what place it held for many people.
He looked at all the furniture that was left standing, raised his head and saw the marks left were Yosef's.
Paintings used to hang and slowly as if by themselves, his eyes moved to the vacant corner where the piano used to stand.
On the floor were black marks left by the wheels when it was pushed out to its new life.
Sadness filled his heart, understanding that a whole life full of experiences in this special house had come to an end.
And for a moment, he almost regretted buying the house.
He had no idea what to do with the property he purchased.
From the start, he had no intention of operating it as a hotel.
He was entirely occupied with his work in the military zones in the south with the heavy equipment he owned, with which he made his fortune.
As he told the singer in the end, he would probably sell it as individual houses as they were originally.
He got up slowly from their armchair, and as he was about to leave, the door suddenly swung open and in front of him stood the girl of this house, Lyara.
Dressed in a uniform with corporal stripes and a guide's lanyard, her hair braided, her blue eyes moist and sparkling, perhaps with tears.
Hey, she said in surprise with a slightly hoarse voice.
How are you, Yehuda?
I'm fine.
More importantly, how are you?
Are you okay?
A sad look crossed her face.
I came to see Carmela Zivik.
We arranged that I'd come when I finish my squad commander course, and I still can't grasp that he's gone.
Just like that, it's simply inconceivable.
My heart is broken.
Tears welled in her eyes, but as always, they stayed there.
Since Lucy passed away, they don't fall anymore.
Now he understood why it seemed she had cried.
Yes, he said sadly, it's really a very sad story.
He looked at her in uniform, still appearing like a fragile girl with a braid adorning her shoulder, and only in her eyes was that deep, mature look.
When I came out from there, I decided to come and see what became of the house.
I thought maybe seeing it would make me feel better, but the truth is I'm just stunned that everything remained as it was, as if frozen in time.
It's been almost five months, and you haven't done anything with it?
She nearly scolded him.
Yehuda looked at her and started to say something, but immediately fell silent.
What could he say to her?
In the end, he said in an unsteady voice, I have no idea what to do with this house.
I have no intention of operating it.
And until I decide, it just stands.
Every now and then I peek to see that everything is okay.
Silence fell between them.
Tell me, Yehuda, are you also not locking it?
She asked.
Not always.
I feel maybe I should.
It's not right.
The days are gone when all the houses around were unlocked.
But what would anyone take?
Glasses?
Chairs?
She felt how every word he said intensified her anger that her lovely house had turned into a useless object.
felt an uncontrollable urge to clean and water the garden or what was left of it.
Sometimes when I come, I turn on the sprinklers for about half an hour.
He suddenly said as if reading her thoughts, but it's hard to say this is the garden you remember.
I know you kept it for your mom, Yossi the Postman told me.
Again, a long silence fell between them.
Suddenly out of nowhere, she looked him straight in the eye, a serious expression on her face.
And quietly and earnestly said, Tell me, would you mind if I come here on weekends when I have leave from the Arnie?
I'll kind of take care of the place, and I'll also have a place to stay.
Just temporarily until you decide.
As the words left her mouth, a wave of panic washed over her.
From daring to ask, maybe from the very idea, Yehuda sank deep into the armchair, as if the air had left him.
He instantly understood that she needed a place to rest her head, that she was homeless.
that the apartment Joseph moved into with his new partner wasn't her home.
He saw the pain in her eyes, seeing her formerly well-kept house neglected and dusty, left as an unused object.
Without noticing, he reached into his pocket and pulled out the key to the front door.
Take this," he handed her.
The key.
Make yourself a copy and leave mine behind the shutter on the kitchen window ledge.
The rooms remain as they were, so choose one and settle in.
She extended her hand silently to take the key from him, feeling his hand quietly and soothingly clasp hers.
just temporarily until you decide, she said with a trembling voice.
And he smiled at her with a sad smile, replying just temporarily in return.
He got up and left before she could notice his emotions.
Something about this charged moment and the courage she possessed without even knowing moved him almost to tears.
Only after leaving did he remember he had forgotten to tell her the singer had been there looking for them.
She stood there, watching his retreating figure, holding the key in her hand, understanding that something significant had happened just temporarily.
